news.title: Legal Discussions with Vengai Madzima: Compulsory Land Acquisition and Compensation by the State in Zimbabwe
news.content:
NewZimbabwe.com hasinvited Mr. Vengai Madzima, the Senior Partner at Madzima Chidyausiku Museta Legal Practitioners (MCM Legal), to discuss with us legal issues that affect Zimbabweans. The discussions are of a general nature and those seeking specific legal advice should contact their lawyer.

Reporter: Welcome back Mr. Madzima, there was a recent landmark judgment in the Zimbabwe Courts on land acquisition and compensation by the government which may affect some acquired land, what was the case about?

VM: Yes, there was indeed a landmark constitutional judgment delivered on 29thJuly, 2025 in Alistair Michael Fletcher v Minister of Lands, Agriculture, Fisheries, Water and Rural Development and others.

Well, I will attempt to summarise the facts. The land in question is in Umguza on the peripheries of Bulawayo City. It was incorporated into the City of Bulawayo through a statutory instrument issued by the President in 1999. Sometime in 2000, the land was subsequently gazetted for acquisition by the State under the land reform program and caveats were placed on the title deeds to perfect the acquisition.

The main issue for contention was whether or not the land was capable of acquisition under the land reform program which targeted agricultural land, as the land had become urban land by means of the statutory instrument of 1999, I referred to and various correspondence from the Bulawayo City Council which referred to it and adjacent lands as urban territory.

Reporter: At face value, it appears simple enough, what where the main areas of contention?

VM: It may appear so, however, there was a conflict in the understanding and application of various constitutional provisions. Main being the interpretation of S16B (2) of the old constitution which limited the rights of individual to challenge the acquisition of land for agricultural purposes after it has been gazetted and conversely, the rights of the courts to adjudicate on such cases where land was acquired under the land reform process. S16B (3) of the same constitution reserved judicial review powers with the courts where expropriation was not in terms of section 16 B(2) as was eventually decided in this case. The other constitutional questions which had to be decided included the right to hold, use and not be deprived of property and the right to equal protection and benefit of the law in situations where the application of s16B(2)a was challenged, which section is now s72 of the new constitution.,

Reporter: What was the decision of the court and its reasoning?

VM: The Constitutional Court agreed with the decision of the High Court that the land in question was urban land by virtue of it being classified as such by law and the City of Bulawayo, that being so, the State cannot compulsorily acquire urban land without compensation by using the constitutional provisions reserved for land reform acquisitions.

Compensation in land reform acquisitions is limited to improvements made on land.

In reaching its decision, the court considered the meaning of agricultural land in terms of the constitution and whether Mr. Fletchers land can be classified as agricultural land. It also considered its own jurisdiction to hear the matter on the basis of whether the land in question was agricultural or urban land.

Reporter: What are the key takeaways from this judgment?

VM: Key takeaways are that the land reform constitutional provisions ousting the authority of the courts to hear and determine acquired land refer only to agricultural land.

The courts still retain the right to hear cases to confirm whether such acquisition was done in terms of the constitutional provisions and for cases referring to compensation of improvements.

The courts also upheld the constitutional provisions relating to right to property and equal access to the courts for all urban land.

The other takeaway is not mentioned in the judgment but is necessary as it reasserts the position that our court system still functions; this is a clear case separating the government and judiciary in their interpretation of the law.

Reporter: How will this judgment affect owners of tracts of land in periurban areas?

VM: In my view, it brings certainty that once land is classified as urban land, it is not capable of compulsory acquisition under the land reform program or acquisition without compensation. It will assist developers and investors in their planning, knowing there is precedent from the highest court securing property rights

Reporter: Thank you, Mr. Madzima, we have to end here because of our time.

VM: Thank you.

news.title: China committed to supporting Zimbabwe’s education, industrialisation: Envoy
news.content:
By Xinhua

CHINA is committed to supporting Zimbabwes ambition of achieving a heritage-based, inclusive, equitable, and quality education and industrial development, Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe Zhou Ding has said.

Zhou made the remarks last Thursday at the official opening of the three-day Scholastica Expo in Bulawayo, Zimbabwes second largest city.

The expo focuses on education, training, and careers in a bid to bridge the gap between the classroom and the corporate world, providing students and professionals with insights into various career paths and developing relevant skills for the industry.

Zhou said China is actively contributing to Zimbabwes education and industrial transformation by energising the southern African countrys development through strategic infrastructure projects, strengthening its industrial base and workforce through transformative private-sector engagement, and nurturing its talent ecosystem.

Indeed, unity is our strength. This is the essence of heritage-based progress: drawing wisdom from our shared history and building a future where education and industry flourish in harmony. Together, lets turn education into industrys spark, turn partnership into prosperity, and turn innovation into progress, said Zhou.

Zhou said China remains committed to supporting Zimbabwes Vision 2030 and the countrys Heritage-Based Education 5.0, two signature initiatives adopted by the Zimbabwean government.

China also stands ready to share its experience in artificial intelligence development and technological products to support Zimbabwe in enhancing its capacity building, said Zhou, adding that more than half of the African students in China are studying science, technology, engineering, and mathematics subjects, along with agriculture and medicine.

In a speech read on his behalf, Zimbabwean Minister of Higher and Tertiary Education, Innovation, Science and Technology Development Frederick Shava said Chinas success in cultivating economic resilience through a curriculum that promotes the countrys heritage offers compelling lessons for Zimbabwe in creating an education system that produces innovators and solution-providers.

Shava added that China effectively uses technology to promote its heritage and empower local communities to identify and leverage their unique natural and cultural assets for ecotourism and specialized agricultural products, fostering distinct regional identities and resilient local economies.

news.title: COP15 concludes with enhanced global resolve to wetland conservation
news.content:
By Xinhua

THE 15th Meeting of the Conference of the Contracting Parties to the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands (COP15) concluded Thursday in the resort city of Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, with an increased global commitment to wetland conservation.

The COP15 ran under the theme of Protecting Wetlands for Our Common Future, drawing government representatives to highlight the vital role of wetlands in sustaining ecological health, biodiversity, and climate resilience.Adopted resolutions at COP15 include accelerating national and regional actions, enhancing monitoring and reporting, capacity building and mobilization of resources for wetlands conservation, and mainstreaming the wetlands into climate adaptation and disaster risk reduction, among others.Related parties also agreed to strengthen flyway conservation efforts to protect migratory birds, endorsed the establishment of the Global Waterbird Estimates Partnership, and recognized the importance of conserving river dolphins and other inland wetland indicator species.A key outcome of COP15 was the Victoria Falls Declaration, which emphasised the need for increased resource mobilisation, political commitment, and investment in wetland protection and restoration.In her closing remarks, COP15 President and Zimbabwes Minister of Environment, Climate and Wildlife Evelyn Ndlovu urged all contracting parties to embed the commitments of COP15 into national policies and strategies.Ndlovu called for international cooperation and financial mechanisms to close the resource gap for wetland restoration and protection.We also call upon strengthening of synergies with other multilateral environmental agencies and agreements to enable us to address complex, interconnected environmental challenges like climate change, plastic and mercury pollution more effectively and efficiently, she said.This will help us simplify our collective influence on global environmental protection and improve outcomes for ecosystems and human health, while fostering innovation and shared learning for all, she added.

news.title: Train driver in heroic water bottle throwing stunt that saved woman from being run over by locomotive
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

JUST a few metres away from running over an inattentive woman walking on rail tracks, an engineman threw a water bottle that startled her, prompting her to flee with her life.

In a statement at the weekend, the National Railways of Zimbabwe (NRZ) confirmed the dramatic incident in which 23-year-old Lisa Shumba of Mutare, Manicaland province, cheated death by a whisker.A 23-year-old woman walking on the tracks putting on earphones escaped death by a whisker after a quick-thinking engineman threw a water bottle at her to alert her of an approaching train in Mutare yesterday (Saturday), said NRZ.Lisa Shumba, startled by the water bottle which fell in front of her, turned and saw the train.The locomotive hit her as she jumped off its direct path. She suffered bruises on her knees. She was treated and discharged from hospital.The heroic act by the engineman saved her life since the earphones had prevented her from hearing locomotives warning horn.We salute the engineman and appeal to members of the public to avoid walking on the railway lines, especially when putting on earphones, further reads the statement.

news.title: Can Artificial Intelligence Save Lives in the NHS?
news.content:
By Dr Richard Dune

As the UK deploys AI to detect healthcare risks in real time, what lessons can be drawn for regulatory compliance and governance worldwide?

On 30 June 2025, the UK government announced the launch of a world-first AI early warning system for the National Health Service (NHS). The initiative, part of its 10-Year Health Plan, aims to transform patient safety and regulatory inspections by using real-time data to detect early signs of harm, before tragedy occurs.

This system will empower the Care Quality Commission (CQC), Englands independent health and social care regulator, to carry out rapid response inspections whenever AI algorithms detect anomalies in care, such as a spike in stillbirths, preventable deaths, or critical incidents.

In the context of mounting regulatory failures in recent years, particularly within NHS maternity and mental health services, this bold shift towards predictive oversight and digital compliance could not be more timely.

But will it work? And what can healthcare systems in Zimbabwe, across Africa, and in the diaspora learn from this transformative approach?

From Mid Staffordshire, where up to 1,200 patients died due to neglect, to the Lucy Letby case, in which a neonatal nurse was convicted of murdering seven babies, failures in the NHS have highlighted one painful truth: the system doesnt catch harm soon enough.

In 2023, multiple NHS maternity units were under investigation, with affected families saying they were ignored or gaslit when they raised concerns.

The Dash Review (2024) revealed the scale of the problem: the average wait time for a reinspection of Inadequate providers had increased from 87 to 136 days, while some with Requires Improvement ratings waited up to a year. Hundreds of inspection reports were lost due to IT failures, leaving vulnerable patients at risk.

This approach is reactive, not preventive, and ill-equipped to keep pace with modern healthcare risks.

Rapid Response Inspections, introduced in recent years, are an improvement, but still depend on someone raising the alarm. What if the system could detect risk from within  automatically and in real-time?

This is the very problem that digital compliance systems, supervision Learning Management Systems (LMS), and Training Management Systems (TMS) are built to solve.

The first rollout, the Maternity Outcomes Signal System, will go live in November 2025. It will monitor indicators such as neonatal deaths, neurological injuries, and emergency escalations across NHS trusts.

If successful, the model will expand to cover wider incidents, making England the first country in the world to integrate AI directly into regulatory inspections.

These are no longer nice-to-haves. They are essential components of a resilient and transparent compliance ecosystem.

The NHS has long been accused of failing to act on known risks, a problem dubbed the implementation gap.

As Sir Julian Hartley, CEO of the CQC, stated, this approach requires aclearer, simpler assessment framework, but it also demands systems that help providers improve, not just fear failure.

The UKs plan also pledges to strengthen Freedom to Speak Up protocols, with CQC checking whether Integrated Care Boards (ICBs) and providers support whistleblowers.

In a world of machine-learning models and automated alerts, the human voice, especially that of frontline workers and their families, must not be drowned out.

AI should amplify, not replace, human insight.

At The Mandatory Training Group, we believe in embedding compassionate governance into all digital systems, whether thats through supervision pathways, LMS/TMS compliance dashboards, or workforce wellbeing initiatives.

Innovation is exciting, but innovation without people is meaningless.

As Professor Nicola Ranger, General Secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, warned:

Technology has a role, but in todays NHS, one nurse can be caring for 15 patients. Thats drastically unsafe.

Daniel Elkeles, CEO of NHS Providers, echoed this:

Trusts need time and support to improve. Regulation must be collaborative, not combative.

Digital compliance must empower frontline teams, not overwhelm them with automated penalties.

The NHS AI early warning system presents a template not just for the UK, but for any country looking to modernise healthcare governance.

news.title: Zanu PF grabs Chinhoyi council seat amid CCC boycott, voter apathy
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

THE ruling party, Zanu PF has won the Chinhoyi Ward 14 seat in a by-election which the opposition Citizens Coalition for Change (CCC) boycotted.

Of the 2,339 registered voters in the ward, only a third turned out to cast their ballots. A NewZimbabwe.com crew witnessed the low voter attendance at the main polling station at Alaska Dolomite Primary School.

Despite the apathy by the majority of the electorate, Zanu PF candidate Solomon Bizwork garnered 599 votes against his rival Hope Zimbiri, who scrapped only 194 votes. Statistics show that the turnout was 33 percent of registered voters.

Zimbabwe Electoral Commission (ZEC) presiding officer, Taona Pfunye confirmed the results as posted at the polling station.

Bouyed by support from Zanu PF bigwigs, including President Emmerson Mnangagwas advisor, Paul Tungwarara ahead of polls, Biswork promised to champion infrastructural development, including six boreholes to ease water supply crisis in the mining settlement, fixing roads and initiating community business start-ups.

On the other hand, Zimbiri pursued a quiet election campaign if any, never convened a single rally and was literally off the medias radar.

The Chinhoyi Ward 14 post became vacant following the jailing of then-councillor and deputy mayor Chipo Mlotshwa of CCC on fraud charges involving double-dipping in the allocation of land. Her sentence was however commuted to community service.

Meanwhile, in Harares Epworth Ward 6, Zanu PF candidate Civilised Bushe won by a huge margin, amassing 3,022 votes trailed by MDC-Ts Alice Nyahunzvi, who managed 120 votes, while independent candidate Peter Nyapetwa got a measly 23 votes.

ZEC presiding officer, Chenjerai Chirere confirmed the results.

news.title: Two dangerous criminals escape from Zimbabwean prison
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

A DARING escape was reported Saturday afternoon at St Thomas prison facility in Marondera, Mashonaland East province, where two prisoners managed to break free from custody.

According to sources, the two inmates from the D Class classified as dangerous, scaled the perimetre fence and made good their escape in broad daylight around noon, just after a visit by friends and relatives raising fears of an inside job.

Sources told NewZimbabwe.com. that one of the unidentified escapees was serving time for armed robbery while the other for rape.

A thorough investigation is reportedly underway to determine circumstances surrounding the escape and identify potential lapses in security protocols. Reports say the wardens on duty were not vigilant, particularly considering that they were watching over D Class inmates.

ZPCS national spokesperson, Assistant Commissioner Meya Khanyezi

Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services (ZPCS) has reportedly launched a manhunt for the escapees although authorities have remained tight-lipped over the shocking daylight jail break.

Efforts to get comment from Zimbabwe Prisons and Correctional Services (ZPCS) spokesperson, Assistant Commissioner Meya Khanyezi were fruitless by the time of publishing.

The incident has sparked panic among Marondera residents, who were sending alerts on social media in the absence of official warning and appeal for vigilance from ZPCS itself.
